results.markdown_table_response: Goodwill is the difference between the fair value of the assets and liabilities of a business as of the date of the acquisition and the fair value of the assets and liabilities of the business at the time of the acquisition. The fair value of the assets and liabilities is determined by using an accounting principle known as the "stock-for-stock" method. In the Stock-for-Stock method, the value of the assets and liabilities is determined by the assumption of an obligation by the seller. In the case of a business, the assumption is based on the assumption that the seller will be able to pay the obligation. The value of the assets and liabilities is determined by subtracting the amount of the obligation and the fair value of the assets and liabilities of the business at the time of the acquisition.
